headline: CNN Live Event/Special
subHeadline: Reps Bowman, Donalds Debate Solutions On Gun Violence In America; Slew Of Florida Republicans Endorse Trump Over Gov. DeSantis; House Committee War-Games Taiwan Invasion Scenario. Aired 9-10p ET

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: That case may never be resolved, unless more data is gathered.That's it for us. The news continues. Want to hand it over Pamela Brown and "CNN PRIMETIME." Pamela?

utterances.speaker: PAMELA BROWN, CNN HOST, CNN PRIMETIME
utterances.sentences: Anderson, thank you so much.Tonight, two lawmakers, two sides of the aisle, two very different points of view. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP) REP. BYRON DONALDS (R-FL): By whom? The man at 1600? REP. JAMAAL BOWMAN (D-NY): What?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Oh, please.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Gretchen Whitmer -- if she wanted to jump in -- she would kill both of them. Secondly, Biden will kill both of them. Biden passed three bipartisan--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's-- BOWMAN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You know what that -- you know what that's like?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: --pieces of legislation.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You know what that's like?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Biden--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: It's like saying Josh Allen is better than Patrick Mahomes.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Biden--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Come on, now!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Biden passed three--(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: They started their fiery but civil debate, on the steps, of the Capitol. And they'll continue it, right here, in the studio.Republican congressman, Byron Donalds, of Florida, and Democratic congressman, Jamaal Bowman, of New York, they are here to debate gun violence, the economy, 2024, and more. That's coming up live. But first, a wrong doorbell, a wrong driveway, a wrong car, three honest mistakes that any one of us could make, turned deadly, or near fatal, for several young Americans, all within the last week. In Texas, two cheerleaders shot, for opening the door of a car they thought was theirs. It happened in a supermarket parking lot. Heather Roth says she was trying to apologize, to the man, in the car, when he allegedly threw up his hands, and pulled out a gun. The 25- year-old man is behind bars, tonight. Roth was struck by a bullet, but is doing fine. A second cheerleader, 18-year-old Payton Washington was seriously injured, but is said to be doing well. And in New York, 20-year-old Kaylin Gillis, she did not survive, after she turned into the wrong driveway. The homeowner, who allegedly killed her, denied bail, charged with second degree murder. Kaylin's father, understandably emotional, while addressing reporters, after that hearing. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: ANDY GILLIS, FATHER OF SHOOTING VICTIM KAYLIN GILLIS
utterances.sentences: For this man, to sit on his porch, and fire at a car, with no threat, is just -- just angers me so badly. And I just hope to God that he dies in jail.(END VIDEO CLIP) BROWN: And, in Kansas City, another homeowner pleaded not guilty, today, in the shooting, of a Black teen, who went to the wrong address, to pick up his siblings. Andrew Lester is now free on bond. And we got a fresh look, earlier today, at 16-year-old Ralph Yarl, for the first time, since he was hospitalized, after suffering a traumatic brain injury, a family spokesman calling him, quote, "A walking miracle with a head of steel." Well, these shootings reigniting the debate, over guns, in this country, nationwide, and on Capitol Hill. Here's Congressman Jamaal Bowman, just last week, in the halls of Congress, demanding Republicans, act on guns. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: They have control of the House. The American people need to know that they don't have the courage to do anything to save the lives of children.REP. THOMAS MASSIE (R-KY): Would you co-sponsor--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: More guns lead to more death.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Bowman was one half of a remarkable moment, recently, on the steps of Congress, when two men, on both sides of the debate, faced each other.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: CHIPS Act.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Stop!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Infrastructure bill.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Stop!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Safer Communities Act.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Stop!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Historic investments in climate.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Stop!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: $35 insulin.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: High inflation.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Biden will destroy DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Overrun Southern border. BOWMAN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Fentanyl in everybody's streets.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: DeSantis can't run on being a--(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Republican, Byron Donalds, and Democrat, Jamaal Bowman, belonging to opposite parties, debating policy, candidly and freely. It is a rare sighting these days. And we're here to continue that conversation, now.The second-year congressmen join us. And I should note, you two are friends, despite being on--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: --on opposite sides of the aisle.Thank you so much for being here for these important discussions. I think people are just craving civility, in politics, and to hear civil discussions, about the most important topics, of the day. One of those topics, of course, guns, as we were just talking about. In this culture of fear, do you both agree there is a gun violence crisis, in America? Who wants to go?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well, first of all, a couple of things. The tragedies that we see, on TV, are horrific. Just looking at the footage, of the father, talking about what happened to his daughter, going into the wrong driveway, and his grief? That's something that shakes everybody.Two things. One, we do have a criminal justice system that is supposed to hold people accountable, when these tragedies occur. That's number one. So the process does have to work. But number two, this is the balance. This is where this comes into play. Americans do have constitutional rights, to hold firearms. That is in the Constitution. It is our governing document. And unless members of Congress go through the process, of amending our Constitution, that is the law of the land. So, I understand the grief that so many families deal with. But you have more than 100 million gun owners, in our country. They own guns, legally. They own them, lawfully. They respect everybody's humanity. And they use them, for sport, or whatever, and they don't harm other people. When these tragedies occur, it is horrific. But we also have to understand that in our country, we have a balance, to protect all rights, people's right to live, 100 percent, but people's right also to bear arms. They are equal rights that have to be protected. And Congress is mandated to do that. Last piece, I will say. Last Congress, I know there was a bill that came through the House. House Democrats, my colleague, Jamaal Bowman, voted for that legislation. I voted against it. It didn't go anywhere, in the Senate. In Barack Obama's first term, they had control of all three branches. If you remember, they had 60 votes, in the Senate. They could have did everything that Jamaal wanted to do. They didn't do that when Barack Obama was President. Why? Because the data does not support the arguments that we're seeing. The tragedy speaks to everybody. I'm not discounting the tragedy. But when you look at the data, long run, for some of the provisions that he's supporting, the assault weapons ban to be one? "The New York Times" came out and reported in 2014, it had no effect. The Department of Justice reported it had no effects. The RAND Corporation did a study. They said it had no effects, on decreasing the atrocities that we unfortunately do see in America.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well, a couple of things. Number one, I completely disagree with the argument that Republicans are sacrificing the lives of kids. That is not true. Republicans support--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Do something legislatively.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --law and order, in every community, in America.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: It's not about law and order.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Jamaal, you already know this. BOWMAN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: It is about law and order. Do you know why? Because, if you don't take crime, seriously, at the lower level, if you don't take it seriously? It precipitates two things. Number one--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Why do people commit crime?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Can I finish?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I'll let you talk.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: But you're going to crime.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Let me -- because it's a part of what it's--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We're talking about guns.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --because it's a part of what we're talking about.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: A gun by itself is an object, it is a tool. But what we're talking about, it's used in tragedies, where people lose lives.Two key things. Number one, if law enforcement in a jurisdiction does not have the ability to do its job, and hold people accountable, when they break the law?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Who is saying -- why are you saying--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well can I finish? Let me make my point.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Let him finish. Let him finish.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But let me make -- but let me make my point.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: They're doing their job.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Hold on. People are not hearing here (ph), so let's listen.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: We have several jurisdictions, where law enforcement is actually prohibited from doing their job.We can talk about various district attorneys, and various districts, throughout the United States. We could talk about various judges, who actually turned down, holding people accountable, for committing crime. You have Police officers, in our country, who are doing their job. They're locking up criminals. But then, what happens is the D.A. or the judge, turns them loose, on the back side. What you create in that environment is number one, a citizenry, who is thinking, "Man, if the Police can't protect me, then I got to do this on my own." That's why law enforcement is critical, to all of this. We got to continue to do that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Byron, that's sort of the back-end.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But that's one. Now, let's talk about the front-end.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That's after the fact.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But let's -- but now let's talk about the front-end.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Talk about the front-end, please.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: If you believe that we should be investing in poverty? The United States--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Anything poverty.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --the United States government has been doing that to the tune of more than $10 trillion, with the Great Society passed by Lyndon Johnson.But here's what Republicans support. We have long supported school choice, and opportunities, for parents, to find the best place, for their child to attend. Not every academic institution that you might be a red line for, for lack of a better phrase, fits the need of that child. Help those parents get where they need to go. Number two--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Byron, school choice doesn't end poverty.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I'm giving you the tools.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: You all over the place.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Actually, I'm giving you the tools.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, I'm not. It does.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: All it does--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK. Let's hit it in on school choice.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Because school choice leads to economic opportunity.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That doesn't end poverty.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: And economic opportunity leads to getting out of poverty.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We have -- we have an economic system-- BROWN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: It is.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Let's hear what Congressman Bowman has to say now.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We have an economic system, where two of the wealthiest Americans, own more wealth than the bottom 50 percent of the country. We have levels of economic inequality that are worse than the Gilded Age.To truly invest in poverty, you have to reverse the impact, of the disproportionate distribution of wealth that happened post-slavery. The Homestead Act, which gave the entire west to White Americans, both native and foreign-born that kept Black people from getting that land, those homes, and building wealth. Black banks have never been invested in, in the way that let's say the Bank of Italy was invested in that now has become Bank of America, one of our largest banks. You've had Jim Crow, Black laws, KKK, mass incarceration, you've had globalization, where we, with the race to the bottom, chasing low-cost labor, all over the world, taking industrial jobs, out of the Black communities. You know what they -- know what they brought back in? Cops, and drugs and the numbers game. You gave us an illegal economy, and cops, but never repaired the harm that you have caused, which is why Black -- mostly gun trafficking, is trafficked in the Black and Brown communities. And Black and Brown people are killing each other with it. So, we're not talking about dealing with the issue of poverty. I'm talking about reparations, repairing the historic harm, investing in schools. And equitably, right now, if you live in a wealthy community, you get more money for your school, than you live in a poor community. And the poor community's only poor because they were redlined, by the United States Government, via the G.I. Bill! Come on, now!

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Now, let me address a couple of your things.So, the first thing you said is about income inequality. Listen, of course, incomes are not equal, because everybody has different levels of talent, ability. People have started in different parts in life. We both acknowledge that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I will never sit here and say--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Some were slavemasters.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Hold on. Jamaal, let me -- Jamaal, let me--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Got to finish. BOWMAN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But Jamaal?

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Got to finish.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: So, please explain to me why -- let's stay with the racial issue, for a second.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Sure, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Second.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Black people have worse education outcomes, worse economic outcomes, worse healthcare outcomes, and a shorter lifespan. Do you think that's genetic?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well, the first I will say is that economic--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Do you think that's genetic?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, no, actually--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Do you think--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Do you think we still have this--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: --level of racial wealth inequality in America, because of genetics?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, I don't.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: You don't. Hold on. I'm not finished.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We -- I would argue--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Because I actually think Black people, we're talented. We can do it all.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, listen.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But that's me.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: There's no question about that.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Right.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That's why you and I are here.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: There we go. There we go.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We are examples of that, right?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: There we go.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: My point is, we are anomalies. We are outliers to our people writ large. And we see disproportionate harm, to our people, that has to be addressed.Now, in terms of present day. I mentioned the wealth inequality.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We still have a regressive tax code, when it comes to the wealthiest Americans. I would argue that the wealthiest Americans are not contributing their fair share, to our government.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well, wait.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Now -- hold, hold, let me finish.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Tell me.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I would also argue--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Go ahead, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: --that large corporations do not contribute their fair share, to our democracy.And, as a result of that, the government is not generating the revenue that it would need, to reinvest, in universal childcare, which is absolutely necessary, for a thriving society, paid leave, which we're the only developed nation that doesn't have paid leave, universal pre- K, and investments on the front-end, so that we can have better long- term outcomes. Because of historical trauma, in certain communities, those communities, and because of consistent, persistent political harm that comes from the policies, we are not enacting, in Congress? Certain groups of people are not moving forward. Now, the last thing I'll say is this.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We have been trying and pushing President Biden, to pass transformational legislation, to address some of these issues. I want to name a few.The CHIPS and Science Act, bipartisan piece of legislation, passed by the President. The Inflation Reduction Act, passed by the President. The bipartisan infrastructure bill, passed by the President. The Safer Communities Act, passed by the President, which was also bipartisan. Between the IRA and the CHIPS and Science Act, we already see jobs with -- money just started going out the door. $200 billion, created 82,000 jobs, 75 percent, to Republican jurisdictions. So, just transitioning to the kind of leadership we need, from the Executive, the President has done some good things. But obviously, we have to push him to do much more. And we need Republicans, and Democrats, on the same page, to take our country to the place it's never been. All arguments are not going to suffice.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Really quickly. And then, we're going to come back and finish the discussion after this break.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Ooh, really quickly? He's got a lot in there.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: I know.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I got to respond.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: But then you can do the other -- you can do it after the break. But go ahead.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Let me tackle one thing, and we'll come back to the other stuff.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: If you're talking about the ability, for kids, on the lower end of the socioeconomic spectrum, to learn? They have every capability to do that.But what do most kids, who are poor, in America realize, they're in an educational system, where A, they don't have the resources to them, B, some of the standards have been lowered, because the--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, it is true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I've worked, in education, for 20 years.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes, it is -- no, no, no, no.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I've seen the data. My mother worked in education too.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I've seen the data. I've seen the facts.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: It is not true.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Standards have been lowered in mathematics, and in reading.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: It's not true.[21:20:00] DONALDS: But to say, "Oh well there's not"--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We have a Common Core Standards--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: We have cities -- we have cities that have done this.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: We have a Common Core.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: We have cities that have done this.I let you talk. Now, let me talk.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, go ahead.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: It's his turn.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: So, if you're not going to have an adequate standard, for kids, to rise and meet, how do you expect them to go ahead and thrive? That's one thing. That's just one thing.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: All right.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: So, that's why I advocate for, we should actually have many opportunities, for kids, to go find the academic outfit that they need, for their success, because their brilliance is unmatched, but it's got to be unleashed.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: And unfortunately, whether, between a lot of things going on, at home, and things going on, in the public school system, it's not being unleashed.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK. We're -- pause right there.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I'll pause here.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: But I'll let you finish at the other side of this break, because, you're right, you do deserve more time. Trying to be fair here, and equitable.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes, yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: And thank you, both, for bringing the fire and the civility. We're going to continue this conversation.Up next, inside the 2024 race, as we get new insight, into Biden's reelection plans. Meanwhile, Governor Ron DeSantis, losing support, in his own backyard. Why so many Florida Republicans are flocking to Donald Trump, instead, when we return. (COMMERCIAL BREAK)

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: So, tell us. Why did you choose Trump over DeSantis?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well, hold on. I'm going to come back to that in a moment.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK. Finish -- finish your thoughts.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: We got to address some things, America, no?

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: OK. Our tax code is one of the most progressive, in the world. It is not regressive.The top 1 percent pays 20 percent of the entire federal income tax bill. The top 30 percent -- top 40 percent, excuse me, pays over 60 percent. The top 90 percent pay everything -- actually, the top 50 percent pay everything. The 10 percent. Got it wrong. The top 10 paid 90 percent of everything. OK? It is by far one of the most progressive in the world. I think what you're referring to is dealing with FICA and payroll taxes, which everybody pays, because everybody does pay, into Social Security and Medicare. We got to understand that. Number two, we raised more revenue, in the United States, under the Tax Cuts and Jobs Act, some people refer to it, at the Trump tax cuts. We raised more revenue than at any point, in American history, $4.5 trillion. We've never raised that kind of money, in the United States. So, we raise tax revenue, all over the place. Corporations are paying. Rich people are paying. Upper middle-class people are paying. Middle- class people are paying. And trust me they're paying, because if you ask them what's going on, on their tax bill, they'll tell you. So, they're paying the taxes. The problem is here, in Washington, D.C., we spend way more than we have. We just raised $4.5 trillion. We spent $6 trillion, last year, $6 trillion. The President wants to go spend $7 trillion. I mean, that just doesn't make any sense at all. That is not sustainable. We do have to get our house in order. If then you want to talk about all these things, Jamaal that you're talking about. Because the thing that's coming for every American, every American, under this economy, number one has been inflation. We all know it. It's been covered at nauseam. Number two is the fact that if we continue to borrow money, recklessly, interest on the debt, will become larger, than what we pay, on defense, larger than what we pay in discretionary programs. We got to take seriously, the spending, of the American people's money, and we got to do it, in a consistent and bipartisan way, I will add -- I will add, to make sure that we lower our debt that we get on a balanced budget track. Now, hold on. Now, to the other question, about DeSantis.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK. Here we go.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: So, here's the deal. Yes, I have endorsed--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Here's the deal.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --I have endorsed President Trump.Looking at the world, right now, we are on the precipice, frankly, of World War III, in a lot of cases. Russia is heavily involved in Ukraine. China is negotiating with Brazil, and other countries, around the United States dollar. They're becoming way more aggressive, with Taiwan. And in short, they're doing this because they see weakness, with the current Commander-in-Chief, one, Joe Biden. My view, on the presidential primaries, amongst Republicans, is that our nominee's got to hit the ground, running on day one, and be able to say to the world, "Look, American leadership is back. We're not going to have countries and their sovereignties be taken advantage of. We want to actually have global security and global trade and, frankly, global harmony." I remember Hillary Clinton, once said, in a debate, in 2016, that if Donald Trump became President of the United States, we will be on the precipice of World War III. Well, that never happened. As a matter of fact, the world got a lot safer. If anybody's got us on the precipice, is Joe Biden. So, if you ask me a decision, between Donald Trump and Ron DeSantis, what I'm looking for, is somebody, who can come in day one, and get America back on track. Donald Trump has done it once. He can do it again. And I would ask all Americans, you have President Trump, you have President Biden. They've both done the job. The question is who did it better?

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: I'm going to let you respond to that one.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Do we know the answer to that one? BOWMAN

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: We know the answer.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's actually not true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: On Twitter.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's actually not true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: On all these social media platforms.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's not true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: "Come on January 6!"

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Name a statement.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: "Let's go get crazy."

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Jamaal, name a statement.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: "I'm going to meet," he told in his speech, "I'm going to meet you down there."

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Come on, man! Come on, man!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: He tried to brawl with the Secret Service. They was like "Chill President Trump, you bugging, you can't ride with us." He let his supporters come in, past the metal detectors, with guns, during the speech, on January 6.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Oh, that's also not true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: They were carrying wooden crosses, down the street.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That is not true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: This is what he did.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: He knew some of them were armed.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: So, he's endorsing an insurrectionist!

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Not true at all.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: He's part of a party--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Not true at all.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: --that many of them voted, to overturn the election results, and pushed the Big Lie. This is the one man, who's walking--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Democrats have voted to overturn elections, too, Jamaal.(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Brother!

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Well.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Democrats haven't voted--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Choose a double party (ph).

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Democrats haven't voted to overturn election?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: They didn't do that in 2004? They didn't do that in 2000? That's not--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm talking about right now!

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You were bringing up old stuff.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Trump wasn't-- DONALDS

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Trump admitted to -- Trump was caught on tape--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I didn't hear it (ph). Say again. Say again.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Trump was caught on tape admitting to sexually assaulting women. "I just grabbed them" by the, you-know-what. He was recently indicted, in New York, for hush money payments, to a porn star. This is the dude you endorse?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You and I both know an indictment is foolishness. And I will--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Foolishness?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: It's foolishness.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, listen.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: It's political and you know that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: My idea--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Well let me go ahead. I'll raise you one better.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Go ahead.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I'll raise you one better.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Raise it.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Because if we're going to talk about stuff, going on, in the background? You have the President's brother, the President's son, they are taking wire payments, from people, across the globe.Jamaal, I've seen some of the documents myself. They are taking these payments. We've already documented a million dollars going to Hunter Biden, facilitated with other members, of the Biden family, while he's sending in the--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Hunter Biden not running for president.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's -- well dude! Stop that!

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Hunter Biden is not running for president.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Stop that! You know -- now you know better than that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden is the President!

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You know better than that. You know better than that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Joe Biden is-- DONALDS

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Well--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: You don't think he knows what his son is doing?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Well, man, this is--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: He doesn't know what his son is doing?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: You're talking about Hunter Biden, right now.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Come on! You're going to sit here, and tell me, he doesn't know what his son is doing?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Listen.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: OK. All right. Let's--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I'm telling you that the President's judgment is compromised.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: I want to -- I want to get--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's what I'm telling you.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: --I want to bring this back, because we can really go, to a lot of places, here, but I want to go back to 2024, and the two frontrunners, for the Republican Party, and the Democratic Party.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Trump and Biden, they would be the oldest presidents in U.S. history.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: So, what do you see as the future of your party, after Biden and Trump?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: So, the future of our party is Congresswoman Ocasio-Cortez. The future of our party is Congresswoman Ayanna Pressley. The future of our party is Cori Bush, Ilhan Omar, Rashida Tlaib, Summer Lee, Greg Casar, Hakeem Jeffries, Gretchen Whitmer, Greg Newsom -- Governor Newsom, Wes Moore, on and on and on.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: All right, well then let me ask you.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Our bench is crazy!

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Let me ask you this, then.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Our bench is off the hook!

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Hold on, Congressman. Then, would you -- are you going to endorse Biden, assuming he's going to announce?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Oh, yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Or would you like to see one of them?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: If Biden announces a run for 2024, I'm going to endorse Biden.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: You will?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Yes. And then we will do whatever we got to do, to push him, to hold him accountable, to make sure he's responding to the American people. That's all we've been doing.The American people want to see universal healthcare, universal childcare, investments in housing, investments in dealing with climate change. They want to see a woman have a right to her own reproductive rights. This is what the American people want to see, by and large, even in Republican States and counties. So, we're going to hold him accountable to that.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: What do you see as the future of your party after Biden and Trump?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Oh, man, our future's bright! Are you kidding me? We already have America's Governor, in Ron DeSantis. You have Governor Youngkin. You have Governor Noem. You got Tim Scott. You have -- we have so many -- our roster is super-deep. You got people, in Congress, right now, who, frankly, they can do a significantly better job, than a lot of people--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I could beat everyone you just mentioned in a presidential debate.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Hold on, man! I let you talk.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: In--(CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: No, you don't. Because you can't even stand next to me, in presidential debate. But let's move on.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I could beat any of them you just mentioned.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Are you going to let me talk? Or you're going to finish talking?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I'm sorry. My brother, I'm sorry.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: OK. There we go, here we go.But let me go back to what the American people need. We have a problem, at our southern border, created by Joe Biden. The southern border is a mess. It is created by the President, on purpose. There are 70,000 deaths per year from fentanyl, per year, since he's been President of the United States. We were talking-- (CROSSTALK)

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: So, not much of what you just said was true, but I'm going to leave -- I'm going to leave-- DONALDS

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: --I'm going to leave you to that.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: That's -- I'm letting you respond to him.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Every part of it is true.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: So, I have -- I have also visited the border.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Sure.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: And I met with Border Patrol Police. And they told me well over 90 percent of the people they stop are not committing any crimes at all. Their only crime is seeking asylum in our country, if you want to call it a crime.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: But you're not allowed--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Hold on, number one.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Hold on, Jamaal? Under federal law, today--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Number two -- number two?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: One second, one thing, real quick. I haven't interrupted you. But I got to stop you here.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: All right. Number two?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Under federal law, today--

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Be quick, hurry up.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --you're not allowed to claim asylum, at the southern border. Joe Biden is ignoring the law, and allowing that process to pass the southern border (ph).

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: OK. Stop there. Stop there. OK. OK. Let me finish.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's the law, folks.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Number two, 70 percent of fentanyl that comes in here is brought in by American citizens. That's a fact.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: That's not passed through the border.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Number three, I've also visited the Northern Triangle, where the majority of mass migration comes from.Have you heard of United Fruit?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Mm.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Have you heard of the Iran--Contra scandal?

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Mm-hmm.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Are you very familiar with the way America, and our Western allies, have disrupted the economies, in Central and South America, leading to abject poverty, hunger, and despair, and how we have funded militaries, and Police, in those countries, to intimidate, so that corporations can come in and mine? We've left them with nothing. That's why they're coming here, seeking asylum.And then third, I've met recently, with one of the top economic advisers, in the country. And the Economic Forum, in our country, one of their main priorities is, comprehensive immigration reform, because immigrants are the engine of our economy. And right now, because of Trump's disruptive policies, they're dealing with fear, and despair, as they try to enter, like Title 42.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: A disruptive policy that unleashed America's economy?

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Here's the bottom line. Here's the thing.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: The disruptive policies that allowed Americans to thrive than at any other time in American history, since the Reagan administration?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: I don't know who--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Those disruptive economic policies?

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Reagan facilitated the Iran--Contra scandal.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: I will tell you this.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: All right, gentleman.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: There are Americans, White, Black, Hispanic--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: We're going to have to--

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --they want those economic policies back--

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Here's the bottom line.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: --because it has worked for them.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: You both have to come back, because clearly there's a lot more to discuss. But I want to thank you both. I really mean that.

utterances.speaker: BOWMAN
utterances.sentences: Of course.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Millions of people in America, they believe everything you just said.Millions of people believe what you just said. I think it is important to hear different perspectives, and to have tolerance for those perspectives. And you both showed that. So, thank you very much. Thank you. BOWMAN: Thank you, sir.

utterances.speaker: DONALDS
utterances.sentences: Absolutely. Absolutely.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Tonight, access to the common abortion drug, Mifepristone, still legal, at least for now, after the Supreme Court temporarily extended a block, on a lower court ruling that would limit access to the drug.The new deadline is now set, for this Friday evening. But it's anyone's guess how the High Court will rule, and what access, to the FDA-approved drug, will look like, in the future. At issue here is the FDA's approval, of the abortion drug, which for the past 23 years, has been deemed safe, and effective, by the medical community. Joining us now is CNN's Abby Phillip. So, let's talk about today. There's already so much uncertainty, and confusion. Today's administrative stay essentially just adds to that, right? So what can we expect from here? ABBY PHILLIP, CNN ANCHOR & SENIOR POLITICAL CORRESPONDENT: I mean, I tend to kind of believe that if they had the votes, today, to either allow Mifepristone, to continue to be utilized, as it has been, for the last 20 years, or continue with Judge Kacsmaryk's ruling, as a -- on a permanent basis, they would have done it. But they're not doing it, because they need more time. They need more time either to take a look at the briefs. And there have been a lot of briefs that have been filed, especially over the last several days, to the court. Or, they need more time to sort out where the votes are, and to sort out where whether or not there are going to be written opinions. I think there have been a lot of legal experts, who have said, "We're not just going to get a judgment here. We may get some actual rationale and some explanation." And that is probably all we know, at this moment, and we'll see what comes next. But this is a really uncertain time, for the abortion rights movement. Because you're looking at a court system, not just the Supreme Court, but a court system, at the federal level, that is probably the most conservative, as it has been, in several generations.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: And it's interesting too, depending on how the court decides, because we know what happened right, after Roe v. Wade was overturned. And so much of that opinion was about letting States decide, leave it up to the States.But if the High Court upholds the lower court's opinion, on this, from the judge?

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: That single judge in Texas? That would essentially have a huge impact, on the States that have a--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: --that are -- allow abortion.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: And I want to also note, this is, it's dubbed often an abortion pill.

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: But I know people, who had a miscarriage--

utterances.speaker: PHILLIP
utterances.sentences: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: --or they had a pregnancy that wasn't viable, and they relied on these pills, to take. So, I just think, also, there was a lot of complexity, to this issue, right? And it's going to be really interesting to see how the High Court decides. PHILLIPYou do have to wonder how much, is the court weighing that. How much is the court weighing the preponderance of evidence, over 20-plus years of approval, versus weighing, what is a clear ideological effort, on the part of the people, bringing the case, to take this drug, off the market, so as to reduce the number of abortions that are happening in the United States? That is such a huge part of this picture here. And I also think that as it relates to just healthcare in general, we've seen, the stories are already happening. I think the chilling effect is already there, on the healthcare community. We see it in the anecdotal stories that are all across the country, about doctors, who are just hesitant, to treat patients, with very complex gynecological conditions, because of the legal environment, around all of this.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Tonight, another sign, of growing tension, between China and Taiwan.The U.S. House Select Committee on China is hosting a war-game scenario, to play out how a potential Chinese invasion, of its neighbor, could unfold. The simulation comes, just over a week, after China's Military conducted live fire drills, around Taiwan, in response to the Taiwanese President's visit to California, this month. CNN's Chief National Security Correspondent, Jim Sciutto, is here with us. So, this clearly signals that lawmakers are taking this very seriously. They are concerned, as China continues to seemingly take steps toward invading Taiwan.

utterances.speaker: JIM SCIUTTO, CNN CHIEF NATIONAL SECURITY CORRESPONDENT, ANCHOR, CNN NEWS CENTRAL
utterances.sentences: No question. Lawmakers are concerned. The Intelligence agencies are. The Pentagon is.And most importantly of all, Taiwan is concerned. I spoke to the Foreign Minister, last week. And he watched these exercises unfold, a little more than a week ago, and said these are not just symbolic that they are signs that China's preparing for war. So, you have this committee, now, war-gaming, which is something that the Pentagon does frequently, and we're seeing on the Hill now, to see how this might play out. And just, for folks at home to have a sense, of what war games have shown, so far, CSIS, another think tank did 24 -- a series of 24 war games, in January. And the losses, in a conflict, like this, over Taiwan, are staggering. We haven't seen, as a country, losses like this, since World War II. In their exercises, both sides, by the way, lose dozens of warships. Not one or two dozens. They lose thousands to tens of thousands of servicemembers, many dozens of aircraft, as well, on both sides. So, two aircraft carriers, in the war games, they carried out, the U.S. losing two aircraft carriers, which as you know, each one carries 5,000 sailors. So, the scale of this conflict, if it were to break out, these war games show would be beyond anything we've seen, since the middle of the last century.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: And you mentioned, you spoke to Taiwan's Foreign Minister.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Let's listen to what he said.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Is Beijing, in your view, threatening Taiwan, with war?JOSEPH WU CHAO-HSIEH, TAIWANESE POLITICIAN, MINISTER OF FOREIGN AFFAIRS OF THE REPUBLIC OF CHINA: Yes, indeed. Look at the military exercises, and also their rhetoric. They seem to be trying to get ready to launch a war against Taiwan. (END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: I mean, he was really direct there.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: He was. And one reason he said that, to me was those exercises that -- they were a joint strike, in effect, an air, land and sea attack, on Taiwan.That's not just a cert -- that's not just encircling the island, blockading it, which is an option that have been discussed that China might consider. That is an operation, to take over the island and with enormous Military casualties, but potentially civilian casualties as well. We don't know that China is going to do this. But we do know that the CIA Director said, in public testimony, that he believes Xi Jinping has told his Military to be ready, by 2027, to do just that. So, tonight, as we're speaking, members on the Hill are now war-gaming this out, to see what it would look like. And based on what they've seen so far, it's not pretty.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: That's frightening.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: All right, Jim Sciutto, thank you. Congrats on the new show, by the way.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Thanks so much.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Catch "NEWS CENTRAL" tomorrow, at 1 PM Eastern.

utterances.speaker: SCIUTTO
utterances.sentences: Appreciate it.

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Tonight, former Fox News anchor, Gretchen Carlson, explaining why she didn't want Dominion to settle, with the Network, even though she reached her own $20 million settlement, with Fox's parent company, after alleging sexual harassment, and retaliation.(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GRETCHEN CARLSON, FORMER FOX NEWS ANCHOR
utterances.sentences: As somebody who's also had a very high-profile lawsuit, against the former CEO and Chairman of Fox News, Roger Ailes, as somebody who's been silenced as a result of that -- with being able to tell all the facts of what actually happened to me -- you know, I was vicariously living through Dominion, and hoping that they would be able to get to the truth.

utterances.speaker: COOPER
utterances.sentences: Yes.

utterances.speaker: CARLSON
utterances.sentences: I would love to be able to reach out to all of those Fox News viewers and hope that somehow we could get them back into the reality of what's really going on. But I think we're so far gone in this fake news era that I'm not necessarily hopeful about that.(END VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: BROWN
utterances.sentences: Fox still faces a $2.7 billion defamation suit, filed by Smartmatic, another voting technology company.Up next, on "CNN TONIGHT," Alisyn Camerota speaks with Fox News viewers, about the network's settlement. Will it change how they see Fox? Alisyn, this will be interesting to see. I cannot wait to watch. ALISYN CAMEROTA, CNN HOST, CNN TONIGHT: Thanks, Pam. It was really interesting to talk to them. It certainly was eye-opening for me. So, thank you, hope you tune in. Good evening, everyone. I'm Alisyn Camerota. Welcome to CNN TONIGHT. Every night, this week, we've reported, on a young person, in America, getting shot, after making an innocent mistake, ringing the wrong doorbell, pulling into the wrong driveway. And now, opening the wrong car door. Two teenage cheerleaders, in Texas, shot, in a grocery store parking lot, after they mistook the suspect's car, for their own. On Saturday, in Upstate New York, 20-year-old Kaylin Gillis was shot to death, in a friend's car that pulled into the wrong driveway. Her grieving father explains what he hopes, happens, to the shooter. (BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

utterances.speaker: GILLIS
utterances.sentences: Angers me so badly. And I just hope to God that he dies in jail.(END VIDEO CLIP)
